dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glimpses of an ancient city.   Almost motionless against the tide of time. Sea swelled along an endless wall. Billowing silk frozen against the sky. Birds lighting on Byzantine columns. FINAL IMAGE is of an imposing STRUCTURE beyond the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corridor of ancient stone and steel extends into infinite darkness. Stale air hangs in the dim half-light like atomized ether. There is WHISPERING.   And tangled VOICES. DRIFT IN PAST prison cells the size of closets. Brief flashes of carved faces, insanity -- COMING TO REST ON th

dialogues.speaker: FINAL CELL
dialogues.text: A gaunt PRISONER kneels on the granite, head bowed to a wall hung tapestry of Christ. But he's not just praying. He's digging. With his arm under the tapestry, he scratches at the stone with a SPOON. After only a year, the spoon finally breaks through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prisoner claws his way between ancient walls, comes to a dead end against a thick wooden door. He nudges a shoulder against it, digs in and pushes. DOOR GROANS open, sucking air into the pitch black CHAMBER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tapestry covering the HOLE is pulled against the wall, then billows outward like a sail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pulls himself inside, chokes in the heavy air. He scans the musty room. Antique furniture. A few empty crates. And the remains of several deteriorating skeletons.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He looks to the far wall, sees a hint of light above through the crumbling limestone. A way out. Too high to reach, Prisoner pulls an old CHEST out of a cobwebbed corner and slides it under the light. He steps up onto the chest, grabs the edges of the hole and starts to shove off when the top of the chest gives way and his foot crunches through. Prisoner reaches down to free his foot when he sees something inside -- wrapped in a red cloth. He pulls it out and as he unwraps it, he discovers the cloth is a Nazi flag. At the center is a crudely-shaped IRON RELIC. Eight inche long. Stains on the edges. Could be the petrified tooth o some prehistoric animal. Or maybe an ancient arrowhead. As he holds it, feverish sweat starts to form on his face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From BEHIND. As if he's being watched by someone else. Prisoner spins, looks back AT us. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: starts toward the way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard's flashlight beam probes the cell -- one by one -- falls on the tapestry. Christ billows out from the wall, revealing the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALARMS SOUND.    Lights BLAST ON.   Guards with weapons r through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prisoner squeezes toward light, grips the relic tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIRENS BLARE as SPOTLIGHTS sweep across the ominous structure. Prisoner breaks from the darkness, runs for the trees on the other side of the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Turkish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!   Stop! Prisoner spins, griping the relic tight. GUNSHOTS RING OUT. Bullets streak toward him but never hit their target. Guards check their weapons on the run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prisoner breaks from the trees, runs into a road. Headlights wash over him and TIRES SCREECH. Prisoner spins, is right in the path of a car. BRAKES SQUEAL -- car locks up but too late -- IMPACTS Prisoner who is violently thrown and lands in a heap. CAR slides to a stop. DRIVER jumps out, sees the front end sheet metal has accordioned all the way to the tires. He scans the area for a body, spots the Prisoner and is stunned to see him getting to his feet. Uninjured. Prisoner is just as amazed. He glances at the RELIC in his hand, notes the wrist has reddened and an odd SYMBOL has appeared as if embossed in the flesh. Driver calls out but the Prisoner is spooked, runs off. OVER this we hear -- A CHILD'S SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER HENNESSEY (50), stands over a young teen (13), JEANIE, splashes holy water on her body. She screams again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Et separatur a plasmate tuo, Ut num quam laedatur amorsu antiqui serpentes! Her body convulses, pulls against the bandages tying her hands and feet to the bed frame. Notice her fingernails. Drained of color. Almost black. Her MOTHER is off to one side, completely hysterical. On the other side is a crowd of bewildered TENANTS, all crammed into the hallway outside the opened door.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nothing can compare with an exorcism.   Especially one that's gone bad. The rather obese Priest tries to steady his hands and his heart. It's obvious he's totally out of his league here. GIRL lets out another SCREAM that ECHOES OVER --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in a third world country but smack center in one of America's richest cities. Sparkling high-rises tower in the distance while flashy billboards tout the sexiest fashions, the hottest automobiles and the smoothest malt liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A faded yellow taxi PULLS UP and stops. Someone steps out, grinds a cigarette butt into the asphalt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doors open, flood the musty darkness with a brief relief of sunlight. A MAN -- whose face we don't see -- steps inside, his trench coat hanging like the folded wings of a raven. He pauses, pulls an ORNATE LIGHTER and lights a cigarette. Takes a puff and pushes on inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lined with tenants trying to get a glimpse of the unexplainable. The Stranger pushes through. Suspicious faces step out of his path. The ones that don't he pushes aside -- even the gangbangers. The man has no patience for politeness, no time for tact, no fear of anything. This man is JOHN CONSTANTINE. He arrives at his destination, barges into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One scan of the situation is all it takes. The bed -- the child -- the panicked priest -- who rushes to John. HENNESSEY (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God you're here... John shoots him a disgusted look.    Hennessey gives him wide berth. John walks past the panic-stricken MOTHER without a glance, sets his cigarette on the nightstand, the glowing tip drooped over the edge. He puts a gloved hand to the child's face and it burns on contact. His demeanor instantly changes as he leans right next to the ear of the little girl and whispers -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Constantine. John Constantine, asshole. The girl JOLTS, bandages on her arms cut into her skin. Eyes snap open -- glare right through him. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doing? JEANIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vamos juntos a matarla. John whips out a key chain crammed with medallions. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see who we got here... He holds them up so they cast shadows across Jeanie's face. He flips through each of these sculptured SAINTS until the child suddenly reacts to one -- tries to look away. John stares at the Saint responsible, seems genuinely puzzled. He turns to the Mother -- very serious. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a mirror. Now. Shaken, the Mother produces a small compact.   John pushe it away, turns to the doorway crowd. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large mirror. At least -- (sizes up the child)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- three feet high.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The hallway crowd discusses possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: MOVE.
dialogues.text: Tenants run to retrieve a mirror.     Hennessey looks worried. John grabs the bed -- shoves Hennessey aside as he swings the bed around, legs gouging hardwood all the way. Faces it toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT 5G BELOW
dialogues.text: Several of the MEN from the hallway crowd storm through an OLD WOMAN'S stuffy apartment, locate a huge iron- framed mirror and rip it and half the plaster from the wall.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: centers on a drapery ROPE, pulls hard. Drapery HOOKS EXPLODE off the curtain rod as he swings open the window, looks down into the alley where that yellow taxi is parked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaz? CHAZ (20s) looks up from his cab. Cool. Frustrated. You just know he'd love to be up there, not down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MOVE THE DAMN CAR.
dialogues.text: John frees the drapery rope, ducks back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Park the car -- Move the car... Chaz shifts into reverse, moves the car three feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, I moved the damn car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four men struggle to carry up that enormous mirror. The Old Woman follows, begs them to be gentle. They swing the mirror around, take out a chunk of banister. She freaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hennessey can only watch as John threads the drapery rope through the fire escape railing, drapes it back through the window and loops it over the ceiling fan. He climbs onto the bed, leans over the child whose eyes have closed and she's shaking badly. Her body seems to be going into shock. Isn't strong enough for this. John has no choice -- slaps her. Eyes pop back open. Dark and dilated. He yells down at her in Aramaic and English. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amar natash bow basar! -- Rescind from the flesh I command thee -- The girl chokes as if ready to spit. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it -- time to go home. Jeanie SCREAMS -- JEANIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiempo para morir! Her body suddenly PULSES half again larger. John recoils for a beat. Odd. He continues in Aramaic -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amar natash bow basar -- Another PULSE and this time a SHAPE is clearly seen expanding under the child's skin -- as if the demon inside were trying to burst right through. John backs off -- watches as the shape ripples her flesh, like fingers caressing from the other side. John glances to Hennessey. What the hell? MIRROR arrives at the doorway, BANGS against the JAM. John waves them in. The four men heft it into the room. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lift it.   Over the bed.   Up.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John ducks, settles on the girl as they raise it over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hennessey, tie it off -- Hennessey is glad to be called into service -- quickly ties one end of rope to the mirror. John straddles the girl, positions his head between her and the mirror above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now close your eyes -- all of you -- and whatever happens -- do not look into the mirror. The men close their eyes.        Muscles tense under the weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amar natash bow basar! -- rescind from the flesh I command thee! Jeanie reacts -- that SHAPE reappears, contorts the young body all out of proportion. John unblocks the mirror for a second and Jeanie is reflected inside. It's not just the image of a young girl in there, but something else. The surface of the mirror FLEXES in the hands of the men. One starts to look --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Jeanie SCREAMS -- breaks free of the straps. She rises up, grabs John tight around the throat. Nails dig deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking into mirror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet! John struggles, puts his hands over her mouth -- cutting off her air supply. Question is, who's going to pass out first? Jeanie's body is racked by whatever's inside her. She goes into shock, body collapsing -- shaking -- close to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look!   Look at me! But she's passing out first. John quickly takes the medallion that caused the earlier reaction --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamit -- look! -- and presses it against her forehead. Eyes snap wide and John unblocks the mirror. Jeanie locks on her reflection and the image in the mirror changes drastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile pretty you vain prick. The child's reflection has now changed to a pissed off DEMON. One that knows it just got suckered in. MIRROR VIBRATES wildly in the men's grip. Demon reflection ripples the glass -- bending it outward into three-D space as the girl takes her last breaths --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Hennessey. Now! Hennessey PULLS the rope with all three-hundred-plus pounds as John gives the demon face a full extended FINGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your boss. Demon pushes for him but mirror is jerked into motion. Swings right out the window but catches on a sliver of wood --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't. John jumps up and helps push the mirror free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falls SLOW MOTION from the 7th story -- tumbling end over end, sunlight beams glancing off the glass, PROJECTING the image of the Demon into the LA cityscape. ONTO buildings, sidewalks, a passing truck -- until all three hundred pounds of IRON AND GLASS come CRASHING down ON the taxi's hood.

dialogues.speaker: SHIT
dialogues.text: Demon's image SHATTERS on impact -- GLASS SPLINTERING into a million diamond-like fragments that choke the air. The GROAN of something evil reverberates into the city beyond. Chaz looks up, sees he missed dying by three feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanie GASPS -- takes her first breath as a child again. And CRIES. Mother pulls her in, hugs her tight. Note the girl's fingernails. No longer black. John's beat, reclaims that stub of a cigarette, still burning. Takes a drag. He pushes past Hennessey who is approaching the mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now about the fee... John slips FROM VIEW into the kitchenette, hides the fact that he has to lean against the door to keep his balance. He catches his breath, looks up and is staring right at a child's crayon drawing magneted to the fridge. A drawing of a figure poking another in the side with a long stick. This image is repeated over and over. John tugs it off the fridge, tucks it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hennessey follows John down the spiraling stairs, passing the gathered tenants. A few are freaked, cross themselves. Others horrified. But many want to touch them, shake their hands. A shadowy FIGURE several floors up stares over the rail at the heroes below. Note the slick suit, the polished veneer. This is BALTHAZAR and he definitely does not rent here. He flicks an ancient COIN between his fingers. JOHN pauses, gazes up through the stairwell as if sensing something. No one there. Balthazar is gone.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOHN shakes off the feeling, continues down the steps where Hennessey is shoving his HAT in front of the tenants. They're gladly giving to the cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.     Yes... Gracias...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hennessey. Hennessey stops his panhandling, continues toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Hennessey stop near the front entrance.      Joh rips the white collar from Hennessey's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know, but I didn't think she was really possessed, not like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not back an hour and you drag me into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Don't be mad, John, don't be -- John rummages through his coat pockets --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the left side. John keeps searching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vest pocket. John rips his smokes from the left vest pocket --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that shit on me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry.    Here, you can have half. Hennessey starts to divvy the cash but John snatches the hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should take it all, save you from yourself. He gestures that bagged BOTTLE in Hennessey's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It keeps them out, so I can sleep. Please, John, I need to sleep. John stares at his pathetic friend, sighs, finally slips a few bills from the wad and hands them over. Hennessey is bubbling with appreciation, starts to follow. John simply holds up a hand. Hennessey stops, watches John walk out. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John turns the corner, spots Chaz punching a dent from the taxi's hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to move it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well maybe if you had told me you were dropping a three-hundred pound mirror with a pissed-off demon in it I would have moved it further. Chaz slams the hood.      They slide into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what? Chaz reaches back into John's front coat pocket -- pulls out Hennessey's wad of cash -- slips off a few bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't have cut your stay in the land of enlightenment. You were so close to growing a conscience. John grins, pulls his special lighter, lights a smoke and sits back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Los Angeles... He looks back up at the apartment, still puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never ceases to entertain. Chaz crams the car in gear as John takes a drag, coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of those perfect days. With perfect clouds. So clear you feel you could reach out and touch Heaven. Two young girls rise INTO FRAME on side-by-side swings. For a moment they're suspended against that incredible sky. Then gravity takes hold and they fall back to Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGELA'S (30) weary eyes open. She's on her belly hidden between track ties and shadows even deeper. Grips a police-issue revolver tight. She's pinned down, unable to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... The MAN is thirty feet down the same track. Their VOICES ECHO off the curved walls, come from everywhere. How either of these two got here isn't important.      Wh will get out is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's next, Detective?   We gonna do a full marathon? Intermittent RADIO CHATTER buzzes from Angela's WALKIE- TALKIE. You get the sense Angela is not alone in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your weapon on the tracks and step out with your hands above your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or how 'bout you show yourself and I put a bullet in your skull just like I did hers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just not going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure about that?! Angela checks the chamber -- sees she has one bullet left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost pleading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now put down your weapon on the tracks and -- GROUND BEGINS to VIBRATE.     Tunnel starts to GLOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ain't this a peach?! Angela looks back, sees several SHADOWS of figures waving far off. Her RADIO is flooded with futzed CHATTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off the tracks! Blueline is coming! Clear the tracks! Angela peeks over the track.     Still no sign of her per The TRAIN is coming INTO VIEW and its BEAM shoots through the tunnel, turning every particle of dust into a superno The SOUND is DEAFENING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Detective, step into the light and be saved!! Angela looks back, squints into the brilliant LIGHT. She grips her GUN and in one burst of flat-out bravado -- rises as she AIMS. And there he is -- the Man rising with his own gun. Angela FIRES as both dive off the track. His BULLET RICOCHETS behind her. Hers finds its mark. Man goes down right in the train's path.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Angela rolls over on the side of the tracks, catches her breath. She closes her eyes and crosses herself as the train roars past in a staccato blur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaz's taxi pulls up, parks.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI TRUNK
dialogues.text: OPENS, REVEALS suitcases stamped with AIR INDIA.   John starts inside, pauses as Chaz yells --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are four bags. I have two hands. This give you any ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make two trips? John walks in.     Chaz curses under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening leagues are going strong. John walks in, looks totally out of place. He moves down the BALL RACK area, runs his fingers across the various leftovers, finally stops at a pearl-white dazzler. He lifts it from the rack, steps out into the prep area -- in front of one of the few lanes not in use. Number 13. John snatches a grease pencil from the overhead, scribbles right on the ball -- "PROVISIONS DEPLETED." He fluffs his trench coat back, steps onto the polished wood with his well-traveled Oxfords. Young bowlers on both sides stop to look at this oddity. An attractive brunette is rather curious. John gives her a wink. Her boyfriend doesn't appreciate it. John bowls. Perfect hook ball. Strike! Brunette grins. John returns the smile, heads into the hallway by the pool tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems small until you walk in and realize it's as long as a bowling lane. Makes that cage enclosed bed at one end seem like it's a mile away. Chaz throws the suitcases on it as John arrives. CHAZ (yells across room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple question. How much longer do I have to be your slave? John pulls a chain and a wall of window shutters open. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not my slave, Chaz. You're my very appreciated assistant. Like Tonto and Robin and that skinny fellow with the fat friend. Along the floor, encircling the entire room, are 5 gallon Sparkletts bottles. Each is adorned by a small hand- marked CROSS. John takes a moment to adjust one out of place. CHAZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much longer? John doesn't like his tone. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't know, what's the going rate for saving a taxi driver hanging from his fingernails about to be swallowed into the jaws of Hell? CHAZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what time you want me back? John gives him a knowing look, goes back to emptying his pockets. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to make an appearance at Midnite's. Say ten-ish? Chaz sighs, starts out -- JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaz...? Chaz turns back, catches an object John throws him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little something from Delphi. It's a dashboard air freshener shaped like a cow. Chaz tips it.     Moooooo.   John finds it rather amusing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, thanks. Chaz leaves. John removes a small BLACK BOX from his jacket. He sets it carefully on its own shelf by the window -- stares out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Provisions depleted?' John turns to see BEEMAN waddle in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave you three months worth. You were gone only one. This diminutive occult version of Bond's "Q" carries a custom bowling bag and squints in the light like a mole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I say, Beeman, India was a real drain. They shake hands.     Beeman sets his bowling bag onto th table, unzips it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything you got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You smell something, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. Incubus in this girl I just exorcized seemed a bit more spirited than usual. Beeman starts pulling things out.      First is a frayed Then glass containers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got your stone fragments from the Road to Damascus, dust from the Dead Sea Scrolls -- oh, you'll love this -- Out comes a little MATCHBOX with a smiling bug graphic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screech beetle from Mount Sinai. He shakes the matchbox and the BEETLE flutters inside. It's WINGS create an eerie HIGH-PITCHED WHIRL. John shrugs. So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, to you it's nothing but to the Fallen -- like fingernails on a chalkboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it with you and bugs? Beeman pulls out a set of sculptured BRASS KNUCKLES. Actually solid gold and engraved with religious markings. John takes them, tries them on. Nice fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gold was blessed by the Bishop Anicott during the Crusades. John spots a foot-long COPPER TUBE in the bag, pulls it out, grips the bicycle handle on one end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it there. With this puny little thing? John gives the handle a squeeze and WHOOOOSH -- ten-foot FLAME BELCHES out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dragon's breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you couldn't get it anymore. Beeman shrugs, modesty. John starts to put it down on the table and Beeman quickly pulls the frayed rag away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, don't want to get a flame near this. (off John's look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piece of the shroud Moses wore to the mountain. John picks it up -- You're shitting me, right?    Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any callinicus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intrigued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How spirited was this incubus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like it was trying to come right out through the girl Beeman just stares at him -- is this a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how it sounds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're finger puppets to them, John, elaborate costumes -- they can work us but don't come through us. They can't. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check the scrolls anyway. Corinthians. See if there are any precedents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, John.   Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coughs again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't happen to have anything for -- Beeman sets down a bottle from the bag -- Vick's 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of blue on blue in this parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locker door opens and Angela is there, covered in the grime of the subway. She's pained as she pulls off her shoulder holster. Looks at herself in the door mirror. Tired, aging eyes stare back. WEISS (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gutsy move out there, Dodson. Angela glances at DETECTIVE WEISS as he opens his locker. ANGELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gutsy?    Well that's a new one. The two exchange a look. WEISS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're alive. Bad guy's dead. No point in using the other words. ANGELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. WEISS (shuts his locker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though it was reckless -- irresponsible -- stupid... ANGELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you still cared. WEISS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're good, Angela, real good but one of these days... ANGELA (heard it before)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, nobody's luck lasts forever. He meets her eyes.    Exactly.     He really does care. Weiss breaks it off, leaves. Angela turns to close her locker door, notices her reflection does not turn. She grabs the door, looks back in. Reflection is as it should be. She shudders, slams the locker door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So exclusive there's not even a line out front. Just a pair of bouncers waiting to roll someone just for fun.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Chaz follows John from the cab to the entrance. A Bouncer selects a PICTURE CARD from a deck. On the front are TWO FLYING DOLPHINS. Only we can see the back, which is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two frogs on a bench. Yep. They let him pass. Chaz steps up and lucky him -- he gets the same TWO FLYING DOLPHINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two frogs on a bench. But Chaz is stiff-armed because the back of this card shows a BEAR in a dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   But I'm with him!   Right, John?   John? John glances back -- gives him an impassive look.   Chaz backs away, stares after him. Someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC FLOODS this exclusive establishment. It's a clash of cultures and influences not easily dated. A retro speakeasy for the new millennium. John walks through a maze of passages while the fantasies of a twisted city play out in the shadows. He pauses, sees a clan of suited businessmen in a corner, showing off for several ladies. One fills a line of shot glasses from a pitcher of water. Another waves his hand over them, turns the water into RED WINE. The ladies are very impressed, drink up. NICO, a young black man, walks past John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neighborhood's going to Hell. John offers a half smile. He likes this kid, walks on. One of the men in the group turns, watches John. Balthazar. He grins and pockets that odd COIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John starts up a long flight of stairs, stops in front of two very large doors.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Their surface is ancient, the wood petrified over countless centuries. John places his fingers into the gnarled folds, closes his eyes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Numquam leadatur a morsu. A living GROAN BELLOWS from the rigid seams but the doors don't budge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastard changed the code again. (bangs the doors)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Midnite! Come on, do I have to huff and puff here?! The doors unlatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEEP ACROSS a meticulously-crafted ORRERY, a scientific sculpture that normally displays our solar system in relative motion. But the planets here are ancient RELICS with symbols and names -- MATERIAL, ASTRAL, SPIRITUAL, ICONIC, etc. And the globe at the center -- "CREATOR." This is an orrery of the forces of the Universe.      And it's not moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Et separatur a plasmate tuo, Ut num quam laedatur amorsu antiqui serpentes... John steps in through the doors behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deciding which color to paint this place again? PAPPA MIDNITE stands in the jungle he calls an office. Part African witch doctor, part savvy businessman. A full six and half feet of solid contradictions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're back early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got tired of spending your money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm sure you spent enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I do have a certain standard of living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me you found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found the vault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, can I help it if Buddhist monks don't take bribes? Midnite strides toward him when John calmly pulls from his pocket a small ebony and gold RELIC. It stops Midnite cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha. A reluctant grin cracks Midnite's stern features. He takes the relic in his thick fingers -- stares breathlessly at a gaunt figure bracing itself against a cosmic wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second century depiction of a sephiroth in the 4th realm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.    So we good here? Midnite ignores his outstretched palm, slides the relic precisely onto one of the many rods jutting from the Universal orrery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It should counter the iconic plane --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That damn thing's never going to balance. Midnite lets go and the complex machine actually starts to move. To turn.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John is somewhat intrigued until the newest relic collides with another and the orrery jams to a halt. Midnite deflates, stares at John, suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must I remind you of what selling fake relics will do to your health?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's authentic, Midnite, you just have the wrong piece. Jesus... The two have a mini stare-down. John's rigid poker face is only broken by a cough. Midnite sighs, breaks it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? -- I didn't blink -- that was a cough. You never cough? Midnite reaches into his tuxedo jacket and hands over a thick stack of HUNDREDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better not be any Washingtons in here this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you cut your trip short? John stops the counting, actually thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... Just a feeling -- John suddenly spins toward the entrance doors, is stunned to see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balthazar. Balthazar is behind him.     Utterly confident.     Chill so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not still whining about Manhattan, are we? John's attempt to disguise his anger fails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That expression alone has made my entire night.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John takes several steps toward him.       Grins.   Malev There's history here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make your night -- I'll deport your sorry ass right where you stand --

dialogues.speaker: JOHN.
dialogues.text: John stops in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's bad enough that you let these half-breeds in at all but this piece of shit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perks of becoming a primary investor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! Midnite's eyes say it all -- not here, not now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things change, balances shift. Get used to it, Constantine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not while I'm still breathing -- John starts to cough again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn't catch that. John tries to catch his breath, can't. And that scares him a bit. He tries to hide it, pushes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John SLAMS out the exit -- coughing. He pulls the Vicks 44 from his jacket, struggles with the child protector cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, John.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John is surprised to see Hennessey waiting. He chokes, is about to bust the Vicks 44 bottle.   Hennessey grabs hold, twists off the cap with one flick. John guzzles the syrup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm real sorry about this morning, John, real sorry. Please don't hate me for draggin' you into that. Please don't... John can finally breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hate you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good to hear. Real good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But could you at least wait until I call for you before you show up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. Jesus, Hennessey, you freak me out sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you want me to go away and come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I've got an assignment for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?   What kind of assignment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kind you'll have to be sober for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, you want me to surf the ether. He instinctively touches an AMULET around his neck. intersecting crosses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you know that exorcism wasn't right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't have the Sight anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have it or don't want to use it? Hennessey vacillates.     This is obviously tough for him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just look around. A few days. You spot anything unusual, anything -- you let me know. Okay? John wraps an arm around his shoulder like a good buddy, then reaches behind his neck --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be like old times. -- and unclips the amulet from Hennessey's neck. That unnerves the big guy. John drops it in Hennessey's pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay... for you, John.      Like old times. Right. Hennessey takes one last sip from his drink, hands the bottle over. John downs the rest. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela sits inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I killed a man today.   Another one. FATHER GARRET sits on the other side of the mesh window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Angela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most cops go twenty years without firing their gun. Not me. I always seem to be in the wrong place at the wrong time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela arrives home. Pours milk for a cat.     Lets her hair down. Slips off her shoes. ANGELA (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't even see his face. I just pulled the trigger and he went away. Just like all the others... Angela in the SHOWER -- trying to wash off the guilt. FATHER GARRET (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These feelings are natural in your line of work, Angela. I'd be worried if you didn't have them. Angela now in a recliner, cat in her lap.   She's tired. Eyes are heavy. FATHER GARRET (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have to be strong. You can't allow your faith to be overshadowed by guilt. ANGELA (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying. Her eyes close. ANGELA (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying real hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela's eyes open. An Angela whose frightened features are dripping with a fever sweat. She's in a hospital gown, stares around a corner. Janitor polishes the floor in the distance. A nurse checks off charts in the f.g. And right between the two darts Angela, unseen by anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A metal fire door swings open and Angela bursts out -- breathing deep. She runs across the tar roof, almost afraid to look back. She gets to the ledge, steps up.   A BOTTLE in the way fall -- FOLLOW IT DOWN TO the --

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: -- where it SHATTERS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound has drawn the attention of BARRY (10) lying in bed. He moves up and stares out the window -- sees the broken glass in the courtyard. He scans up the building and spots a FIGURE standing on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: ROOFTOP
dialogues.text: Chilling April air flutters Angela's gown, vaporizes her breath. Tears stream down her cheeks as she contemplates the unthinkable. Cityscape of lights are spread out below but Angela is seeing something else.

dialogues.speaker: REFLECTED IN HER EYES --
dialogues.text: is a city engulfed in RED FLAMES. Follow that tear with the same reflection of fire inside as it traces her cheek and slips into her mouth. ANGELA shudders, rubs her wrist where we see the skin has swelled and reddened just like the Prisoner's. And there's that same circular symbol in the flesh. She wipes her tears -- tries to be strong. Takes a few breaths for courage, them simply steps off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARRY'S WIDE EYES follow her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry approaches across the barren courtyard, leans down to Angela's contorted body. But she's still alive. Barry stares into eyes that are fading fast. He reaches out, touches her face. Eyes close. She's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela stirs awake.   Disturbed. OVER this we hear INCESSANT COUGHING --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John switches on the light, leans up from the sink and wipes his mouth with a towel. It's covered with blood. More runs down the drain. He stares at himself in the mirror. ON John's worried eyes --

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA'S EYES
dialogues.text: looking equally distraught. WEISS (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her, Angela...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Angela is led by Detective Weiss past several officers and medical personnel. WEISS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Isabel. They arrive at the covered body in the courtyard. Coroner sees Angela approach and lifts the sheet from the face. Angela comes to a dead stop, emotions coming fast and furious. She leans close and we see a mirror of Angela. That's when you realize that wasn't a dream. This is her twin. But that circular symbol is nowhere on her wrist now. Angela's eyes well with tears. It takes everything she has to stay in control. Helps to wrap herself in the job. She steps back, looks up at the tall building. ANGELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She... she fell from the roof? WEISS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   She jumped. Angela gives him an incredulous glare.   Shakes her head. WEISS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's hard to accept but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabel would never in a million years take her own life. Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela... there was a surveillance camera on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John marches down a hallway, his trench coat a step behind. He unconsciously rubs his left wrist, coughs. Flicks an unlit smoke between his fingers. John stops at a doctor's office door -- hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: View of the rooftop. There's Isabel in her nightgown, stepping up -- pausing just a second. Then one step and she's gone. So clear. So unrefutable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela shudders as a comforting HAND rests on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take some time... Angela brushes off his hand, then spots Weiss and the others on the other side of the room. Whose hand was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LINE OF LIGHT BOXES illuminate several CHEST X-RAYS. A DARK sinister splotch snakes through both LUNGS. John stands there, stares at this wall of death with disbelief

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I've beaten things, insurmountable things, things most people have never even heard of and after all that you think I'm going to be done in by THIS? He raises a puny little cigarette. DR. LES ARCHER (50) sighs. A delicate bedside manner is not his specialty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't be the first, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be that simple. I mean come on, Les, you saved me before. You can do it again, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is different. This is aggressive. John tries to stay cool -- fails.     He TRASHES the X-ra boxes. Diseased lungs disappear.      Doc shakes his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty years ago you didn't want to be here. Now you don't want to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because I know exactly where I'm going this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John steps outside of the Doctor's office, pauses to gather himself. He starts walking. Wants out of here fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela is on the move. Emotions are coming in strong. She can't get out of here fast enough. She aims for the elevators, sees a MAN has just entered one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushing toward it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, hold the door! Angela, gets to the elevator, looks in. John stands inside alone. This should be the first time we realize they were in the same hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going down? John pauses as the doors start to close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I can help it. The doors close right on Angela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PICKUP TRUCK crosses a barren landscape. In the back bed are several goats and one Prisoner. He grips the relic tight in one hand.   That anxious feve has returned. Glazed eyes dart to the side and lock on a rising jetliner in the distance -- dart back to the road they're on -- heading the opposite way. Prisoner clamps his eyes tight, grips to the relic tighter. Eyes snap open and he turns, thrusts his elbow through the center window, leans in and grabs the Driver -- jerks his head back against the bulkhead -- cracking it in the process. Prisoner latches onto the wheel, takes control. He swerves the car off the pavement, gets out and takes over as driver. Truck continues on, bouncing through a shallow ditch and into the field beyond, aiming straight for the rising airliners in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close to condemned status. SCAN UP floor after floor, COMING TO REST ON a window covered with aluminum foil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every wall of this tiny shithole is covered in aluminum foil. A sober Hennessey stands surrounded by decades of newspapers and periodicals -- tries to get his breathing in check. He instinctively reaches to his neck to touch the amulet but it's not there. Oh yeah -- in the pocket. Decision made, he reaches up, starts tearing the foil from the walls and the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John sits at a park bench. Motionless. Taking in the world. Clouds passing the sun. Shadows drifting across the city. Leaves swirling after passing cars. John just sits there, HEARING every breath he takes, wondering which one will be his last. ELLIE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lung cancer?   Lung cancer?! John turns to see ELLIE (23) strutting up the sidewalk. Uninhibited. Oozing sex appeal. But dangerous. In more ways than you think. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny as shit, John. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if you guys didn't have something to do with it... ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I think you brought this one on yourself. John stares at her, tries to get a read. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now why wouldn't you trust me? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, something in the air -- She sits right on his lap, playfully. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, John, you'll beat this. You beat everything. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this time, Ellie. John lifts her off of him, sets her aside. ELLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh wow, you're serious... No wonder the Boss is in such a good mood. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I thought maybe you could talk to him for me. You know...?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ellie jumps off the bench, creates an odd SOUND as she does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! Dammit, John, I know I owe you but to even ASK that? All those saints and martyrs slipping through his grasp -- his own foot soldiers sent back to him in chunks. He's going to take all that out on you, John, and he's going to enjoy ripping your soul to shreds until the end of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I take that as a 'no?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one soul the man himself would actually come up here to collect. And you know how much he despises this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starting to see his point. Ellie sits back down, strokes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you gone to see the Snob? Like scratching fingers across a blackboard.     No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, don't let your ego get in the way on this. I'd miss having someone up here I can... relate to. She gives him a kiss. And for a second John's leg is brushed by a tail. John doesn't react. Just turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen through a mild rain is the Theological Society building, a foreboding structure that looks out of place for this city. John stares out the back seat window, takes a swig from a bottle of hard liquor. He turns to Chaz --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I can get you in here. Chaz gives the building another glance, shoves the meter flag back down. Tick... tick... tick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few bishops talk quietly. A cardinal studies Scriptures. Definitely not the place for atheists. John walks through the vaulted chamber room to the --

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARY
dialogues.text: John stops, fixes on the two gentlemen standing in front of a fireplace. One is a young man of pure class wrapped in Armani's best. The other is Father Garret. John stands to the side and waits for their conversation to end. An ATTENDANT makes the rounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I take your coat, Mr. Constantine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, I'm not staying long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you, ma'am? Attendant turns to Angela standing just a few feet away, her gaze fixed on the same two men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not staying long either. John glances over and for the second time they make contact. Something about her eyes. John stares a bit too long. Angela looks back toward the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My business with him is urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First come, first served.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're rude no matter where you are. John gives her a look. The two men shake hands and start to part. John and Angela make their move toward the men. Both are surprised when Angela goes for Father Garret and John goes for -- -- the SNOB, officially known as GABRIEL.       Yes, that

dialogues.speaker: FATHER GARRET
dialogues.text: and Angela have retreated to another area for privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is he stalling on this? My sister needs a Catholic funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela, it's still considered a mortal sin --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't commit suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bishop has read otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father... David -- this is Isabel. (meeting his eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... Father Garret stares at her, tries to be compassionate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to him again. But Angela has just lost a load of faith.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE FIREPLACE
dialogues.text: Gabriel sits in his chair, watches the fire with unblinking eyes. John approaches from behind and against the backdrop of flame, sees the nebulous shape of wings. The ghostly image is visible for only a heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you want, son.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John sits across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been keeping your all-seeing eye on me, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could offer how a shepherd leads even the most wayward of his flock but it might sound disingenuous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're going to make me beg? Angela pauses on her way out, looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't help. You've already wasted your chance at redemption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the minions I've sent back, the souls that I've saved -- that should guarantee my passage across --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keeping it private)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- No -- passage requires faith and faith by definition is belief without proof. You have proof. And that means you're not playing by the same rules as everyone else. Your work has mostly been for selfish reasons. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is bullshit -- bullshit! Now he's really got Angela's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like you've got some cosmic scale weighing everything we do -- help an old lady across the street -- put in a nickel, kick a dog, take out a dime -- you're fucking nickel and diming us to death down here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your voice down.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John jumps up, leans into his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you know what, you're the ones with the problem, not us -- You make these impossible rules to decide who goes up, who goes down and you don't even understand us -- This more than anything gets under Gabriel's skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each of you is born with the promise of salvation preordained. The cost of your redemption is simple belief. And yet you whine about impossible rules. Sometimes I imagine you hardly deserve the gift you have been given.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gift?! More like a curse the way you manage things. Gabriel stands and towers over John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am taking your situation into account, John, but don't push me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me, Gabriel? It's personal, isn't it? I didn't go to church enough? I didn't pray enough? I was five bucks short in the collection plate? Why? Gabriel moves right up to him, makes this very personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to die because you smoked 30 cigarettes a day since you were 15. And you're going to Hell because of the life you took. Or to put it in a way that your kind would understand. You're fucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela stands on the porch at the edge of a downpour. She hears a cough, looks over to see John standing on the other side, looking equally frayed. They share another glance.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John fishes a pack of cigarettes from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has a rotten sense of humor. (steps past)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And his punch lines are killers. John tosses the cigarette pack, walks right into the RAIN, away from Chaz's taxi pulling up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John?   It's raining! Hey! Angela watches John disappear in the rain, looks down at the empty cigarette pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lies on the floor next to food wrappers, Coke bottles and stacks of newspapers. Hennessey sits amongst the garbage, slumped over. But he's not sleeping. He's surfing the ether. Allowing his sixth sense to guide him. His hands move down and across the stacks of newer periodicals, fingers probing the layers of information. Left hand suddenly stops. Hennessey's eyes open. He removes the layers of periodica on top of his left hand, leans close. Edges his fingers away and sees an OBITUARY. A name -- Isabel Dodson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John walks the streets, numb to the world. A rat scurries past near the curb. Then another. Several crows fly by. Above him is a BILLBOARD - "YOUR TIME IS RUNNING OUT." Doesn't matter that below it is -- "TO BUY A NEW CHEVY." The point is crystal clear. John shakes his head, breaks out laughing which quickly turns into a coughing fit. He leans to a gutter. Another rat scoots past. John barely notices. Then a frog jumps past. But it's the crab crawling by that finally catches John's gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy, you got a light? John turns, settles on a silhouetted figure standing behind him, unlit cigarette butt in its mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta stick together, right? John gathers himself. As he walks over to this OLD MAN, he rummages through his coat pocket, retrieves a matchbox. The box shudders as a high-pitch FLUTTERING filters from inside. Old Man winces as his entire body VIBRATES. John realizes -- this is Beeman's matchbox, the one with the screech beetle inside. And now he knows -- a beat too late. Old Man attacks. John is knocked onto his haunches. As the Old Man closes in, he's revealed in more detail. Body and face are actually an intricate puzzle, an assemblage of city vermin. Rats, insects, crows, frogs, crabs -- all held together in the shape of a man. John scampers backwards, just inches from this being's outstretched grasp. He shakes the matchbox and the screech beetle inside flutters again. Old Man/Demon cringes as his entire body vibrates apart for a second, then snaps back together. He GRABS onto John with fingers of squirming vermin. Snake wraps around his wrist. Crab snaps at his skin. John shakes the beetle box harder -- causing the parts to vibrate even further. Old Man grabs John's head and vermin of various leg count crawl right onto John's face. John's had enough -- shakes the matchbox violently, then smashes it against the sidewalk. BEETLE lets out a death SHRIEK and the Old Man stutters -- his parts vibrating so wildly you can actually see the b.g. through the seams. John scampers loose, grabs a road barricade and swings it with all his might. Old Man form shatters on impact.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The entire mess collapses to the ground in a flood of scattering critters. John starts stomping on them as they scatter into the city. John stands there, shocked and concerned.      What the h is going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That surveillance VIDEO FOOTAGE from Ravenscar plays again. There's Isabel in her nightgown walking across the roof. Spread out on a cluttered coffee table is Isabel's case file. CORONER'S REPORT is opened. Let's see "NO DRUGS IN SYSTEM" and the biggie -- "Cause of Death -- SUICIDE." Angela sits on the couch in her robe.      Disheveled and distraught. She's taking this hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Isabel... She lowers her head.     And in that brief moment of silence --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constantine. Angela snaps back to the TV, freezes in shock. There's Isabel ready to jump but this time she's looking right back AT us -- at Angela. Then she's gone. Angela quickly rewinds the tape and watches the sequence again. This time Isabel doesn't look back. This time there is no name. But Angela did see it. Did hear it. She sits for a second.     Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John paces as Midnite works on that Universal orrery, adjusting components but balance continues to elude him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few months, maybe a year. That's it. End of story. Game over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Midnite doesn't react)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't break down on my account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want from me?   A shoulder to cry on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This bastard attacked me right out in the open -- on Sepulveda no less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't like you, John. You've deported how many back to Hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just it -- this wasn't some possession or wayward half breed, it was a full-fledged demon. Here. On our plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have just crossed over and didn't even realize it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't cross over -- It was on this side. Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- it's wet out, you're wandering around aimlessly, not to mention completely emotional --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emotional?! John slams a fist against the counter. The orrery almost topples but Midnite saves it. Decades of work almost lost. Midnite glares at a desperate John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so you saw something. We've seen a few small ones slip through now and then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more than that... first the girl, then this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, you know my connections. Any shifts or tremors in the planes and I'd hear about it. John just shakes his head, looks up -- convinced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's coming. Midnite sighs, gives up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name JOHN CONSTANTINE is center screen on a monitor -- typed into the police station's SEARCH ENGINE. Angela sits alone in the squad room, rain streaking across the windows. Interpol comes back with results and a list of priors scroll under John's name. Must be a hundred PARKING VIOLATIONS. Several SPEEDING tickets and a few RECKLESS ENDANGERMENT. In fact John's license has been REVOKED. But it's the other incidents that draw Angela in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of specific words in a few HEADLINES -- "Occult activity on the rise..." "Claimed possession is refuted by Bishop..." "Satanic cult dissolved..." Accompanies with an assortment of unusual case photos. -- BLOOD PATTERNS on a WALL -- Odd SYMBOLS burned into a ceiling. A cross burnt to a crisp. -- JOHN in handcuffs looking back at a mother holding her son in her arms. A younger and more noble Father Hennessey stands beside them, looking grateful.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Another line -- "INSUFFICIENT EVIDENCE to PROSECUTE." Angela scrolls, sees cities listed where John has made waves -- LONDON -- PARIS -- ROME -- BUDAPEST -- MOSCOW. Stops on the one that matters -- LOS ANGELES. And there's an address. Angela hits PRINT and the HP HUMS away. A desk PHONE RINGS. Angela quickly looks around, sees she's the only one here. She gets up, answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L.A.P.D.   This is Dodson, hello? Dead air. The next PHONE RINGS. Angela reaches for it when the NEXT ONE RINGS, and the NEXT, the NEXT. The RINGS HOP phone to phone in intimidating mockery. Angela freezes, forces herself to stay calm.     Sure enough, the RINGS abruptly CEASE. Angela reaches over, rips the page from the printer, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police guard scans passengers and a printout of the Prisoner. He walks past a man standing in the metal detector line. This is actually the Prisoner wearing the clothes and glasses of the Driver. Is that a blood stain on the lapel? Sweat drops from his forehead and he nervously places the iron relic in a bag he took from the truck driver. He has no choice but to place it on the conveyer belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching the Prisoner.      He looks back AT us, suspicio Nothing there.

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: looks back nervously, as his bag goes through the detector.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTOR SCREEN
dialogues.text: shows the folds of the bag, a wallet, a passport and nothing else. The iron relic doesn't even produce an outline. Bag slides out, untouched. Prisoner can't believe his luck, grabs the bag and walks on toward the gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VARIOUS of the city -- the contrasts between the bright and cheerful and the dark and mysterious. That abandoned mission behind Bob's Big Boy, the Islamic Temple wedged between competing banks.

dialogues.speaker: COME TO REST ON --
dialogues.text: The towering statue of The Good Shepherd. His hands are welcoming us into the "HOLY CROSS CEMETERY." Right across the street is the 20 Lanes Bowling Alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John drinks alone.   Pissed at life.      At death. That small black box of his lies on the table unopened. Spider runs across the table. John flips an empty glass, traps it underneath. He takes a drag on his cigarette, tips the glass and blows smoke inside. Spider can't escape the poison air, bumps the glass. Trapped. Dying. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to my life. ANGELA (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Constantine? John looks up, spots Angela.        Those eyes again. ANGELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you at --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She did make an impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to ask you a few questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not really in the talking mood right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you just listen then? Angela sets her LAPD detective badge on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always a catch... Angela sits across from him, puts the badge away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister was murdered last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name was Isabel.   Isabel Dodson? She looks for a reaction.     None.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never met her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She look anything like you? (as Angela nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would've remembered. Another beat as their eyes meet.       John looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a patient at Ravenscar. Then last Tuesday she just decided to step off the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you said she was murdered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabel would never take her own life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised at what people will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know I'm not making much sense -- hell I'm not really sure what I'm doing here... I just feel -- the circles you travel in -- the occult, demonology, exorcisms... John just stares at that spider in the glass.       Trapp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe someone got to her, Mr. Constantine, brainwashed her into stepping off that roof. Some kind of legion or cult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a theory.   Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I thought with your background and experience, you could at least point me in the right direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay.   Sure. John points -- toward the exit.      Angela is not amused But she's not giving up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister always talked about a world better than this. Heaven as some call it. She wasn't afraid of dying because she knew it was waiting for her. What everyone fails to grasp is that if she had really taken her own life --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- she would have committed a mortal sin and her soul would have gone straight to Hell where it would never feel love or compassion or anything but pain again as the master himself rips her apart over and over for the rest of eternity. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That about right? The words have hit so hard that Angela is speechless. John sees the hurt in her eyes, would like to take it back -- but it's too late. She turns and starts out, slows --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not the only one afraid of Hell. John tries not to let that get to him. She leaves. He glances out the window, watches her pass by. So long. Good riddance. But something's not right. Those deep shadows on the buildings seem to be moving. John watches, confused, realizes they're heading in Angela's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit... He stands, gains his bearings. As he walks out he flicks the glass over. Spider runs free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars are lined all the way down the street. Angela walks along the sidewalk unaware of the shadow following her. It's joined by another in the trees -- both closing in with each step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective! Angela looks back, sees John in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How open is your mind?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She doesn't answer, continues walking. What she doesn't see are the shadows seeping back into the fringes. But John does. He starts walking toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe in Heaven and Hell? (off no answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about what comes out of each? Angela keeps walking.      He catches up with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean like angels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And demons. Angela stares at him, continues walking.       He keeps u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, you don't have the mindset for this kind of work. They walk together down the lonely street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I see terrible things every day. A mother drowns her baby. A ten-year-old shoots his father. But it's not demons, it's the evil that men do. Behind them, a streetlight BLINKS OUT. Then another. They're not looking back so they don't see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, we're capable of terrible things but we usually justify it with motives like money and power and jealousy. Another LIGHT FIZZES, blinks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then sometimes, something comes along and gives us just the right nudge and we do truly evil things just for the kick of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe in demons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should.   They believe in us. They pass another streetlamp as it goes bright, then blacks out. Both look up. The next LAMP FLARES then FIZZES OUT. Angela turns and sees that there are no lights behind them. She looks to John. But he's staring straight ahead. Because now the light in front of them is FLARING BRIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should go... Second later it BLINKS OFF.         John grabs her hand -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast. Angela's confusion turns to tension as a raspy guttural WIND races toward them. John jerks her into action. They run towards the next light. It blinks out right when they reach it. They race to stay in the light, aiming toward the safety of the brightly-lit statue of the Good Shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make it through the gate, pass through an alley of overhanging trees. Something RIPPLES through the branches -- flitters right past Angela's face. She swats at it, manages to get a branch across the cheek. They near the Good Shepherd and the floodlights FLICKER, fade out. Statues of saints become dark monoliths. John stops in an OPEN AREA between trees and a mausoleum. A lit CROSS on the wall provides the only illumination. Angela feels the scratch on her cheek, sees a trickle of blood. Now she hears SOUNDS in the darkness. Like LEATHER RUBBING. Surrounding them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: John is just as surprised he's saying this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wings? John rummages through his trench coat -- fishes out that cloth Beeman gave him. The one supposedly wrapped around Moses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And maybe talons. The cross is getting dimmer and dimmer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something that's not supposed to be here. John quickly wraps the cloth tight around his hand. Angela spins, eyes seeing only darkness as the sounds get CLOSER -- ghastly sound of MOVEMENT in the fringes of light. The cross now resembles a dying wire filament and with every second the circle of light gets smaller and those SOUNDS GET CLOSER. John takes out his special lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close your eyes. They are now standing in pitch darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. John flicks the lighter and in one powerful motion -- sweeps his arm up as he lights his hand. Sacred cloth catches fire -- then IGNITES with a brilliant retina-searing FLASH -- blinding Angela and illuminating a -- -- CIRCLE OF WINGED DEMONS -- a roiling broth of reptilian death -- right there -- ready to pounce.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: RED FLAME radiates from the cloth and DEMONS SHRIEK as they are instantly vaporized. John tucks his burning hand into a coat pocket, extinguishes the flame. He leans down to a rubbery stain left from one of the burnt demon carcasses. Shakes his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'I accidentally crossed over?'    I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming up behind)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that? I saw wings -- and teeth -- they were flying. What the hell were those things?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They weren't angels. John scans the area, trying to think this through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seplavites, actually. Scavengers for the damned. (off her lost look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Demons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You can't be serious... this is impossible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't think they were after me... John looks at her with renewed interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really believe she wouldn't commit suicide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit thrown)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister? (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never in a million years. John makes the decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's be sure. He starts walking.     Angela is now compelled to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple.   See if she's in Hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly an inviting place. Hennessey steps off the curb, looks up at his destination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John stares at a photo of Angela and her father in police uniform. Obviously happier times. Angela walks out of her bedroom holding a cardboard box. That gray cat follows close to her heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are all Isabel's things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, why...? John ignores the box of items, picks up the cat. He studies it a bit, then sits back in a chair with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you need candles and a pentagram for this to work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, do you have any? John puts his feet, shoes and all into a BUCKET OF WATER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to step outside now.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Angela wants to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela?   Please. Angela reluctantly moves toward the exit. John holds the cat, stares into its huge, unblinking eyes. There's a moment where animal and man seem to connect. The water around John's feet begins to BOIL. ANGELA pushes the door closed behind her but it slows on its way to latch. Bulbs pulsate as current ramps down. The room flickers, is suddenly caught in a ghostly dim half-light and John has now crossed over into --

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT IN HELL
dialogues.text: Same layout, different decorator. John takes a deep, raspy breath, slowly stands. He turns to the wall behind him which is torn away, looking like some half-bombed structure in Beirut. Beyond the wall is no longer the blackness of a nightscape but a sickly sepia glow. Not quite day, not quite night. John steps over the crumbling wall into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
